did.abstract: Collection includes scrapbooks, reports, correspondence, member lists, constitution and by-laws, photographs, and meeting minutes.

prefercite.head: Preferred citation
prefercite.p: Columbian Women records, University Archives, Special Collections Research Center, The George Washington University.

acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p: Materials acquired through transfers from Columbian Women.

userestrict.head: Restrictions on Use
userestrict.p: Some material may be copyrighted or restricted. It is the patron's obligation to determine and satisfy copyright or other case restrictions when publishing or otherwise distributing materials found in the collections.

bioghist.head: Historical or Biographical Note
bioghist.p: In 1894, a fire at Ford's Theater took the life of the father of Mary Chapin, one of the original thirteen women to attend Columbian University (it became The George Washington University in 1904). So that she could continue her education, the women students, under the guidance of Professor Charles Munroe, formed a group called "Columbian Women," and raised money for Mary to finish her studies. Membership was open to women students, alumnae, and wives of faculty, trustees, and officers of the University.

The major aims of the organization are the advancement of women at the University and the promotion of the interests of their alma mater. The major portion of Columbian Women's activities is the support of its Scholarship Fund for women students. The first fund was established in 1897 and since then hundreds of young women have been helped through this Fund. Three first ladies of the United States have been interested in the scholarship program - Mrs. Calvin Coolidge, Mrs. Herbert Hoover, and Mrs. Harry Truman. Mrs. Truman entertained Columbian Women members at a White House tea while her husband was in office. Over the years, the organization has also given generous gifts to the University itself, including the hospital, Women's Athletics, and the University Library.

Many distinguished women have been members, among them novelists Dorothy Betts Marvin (wife of former GW President Cloyd Heck Marvin), Mary Roberts Rinehart and Margaret Truman, Judge Sarah T. Hughes, who administered the oath of office to President Lyndon Johnson after President John F. Kennedy's death, aviatrix Jackie Cochran, and the Director of the U.S. Mint, Eva Adams.
N.B. This history note was written in 2005

scopecontent.head: Collection Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Materials in this collection include scrapbooks, reports, correspondence, financial records, constitution and by-laws, photographs, and meeting minutes. They range in date from 1894 to 2009, and were transferred to the University Archives by the historians of the Columbian Women.
There is historical materials related to Columbian Women in MS2278. These materials were gathered by member Dr. Ruth Osborn.
Note: Not all series are processed. Ask staff for assistance.

arrangement.head: Collection Organization
arrangement.p: Organized in eight series: Columbian Women, records, 1916-1980; Columbian Women, records, 1988-2003; Scrapbooks prepared by Columbian Women historians; History of Columbian Women, scholarships and applications, minutes, correspondence, and treasurer's reports; Treasurer's records, correspondence, and Scholarship Committee; Directories, events, and history; Videotapes; and Ramona Stoltz papers.

controlaccess.corpname: Columbian Women, George Washington University, Washington (D.C.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series contains the records of the Columbian Women from 1916 to 1980, including annual reports, minutes, correspondence, scholarship funds and recipients, constitution and by-laws, photographs, and material on the 75th and 90th anniversaries.

Treasurers' Reports and Scholarship Funds Reports

odd.p: Includes Handbook of Duties and the Procedures of Officers and Committee Chairmen, March 1970

odd.p: Program for 17th Annual Dinner of the Columbian Women, 1925; The GWU Highschool Press Conference Program, 1942; Student Financial Aid brochure, 1971-1972

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Photos, letters, and clippings from Embassy Tour, presented to Sue Bernett Panzer

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series contains the records of the Columbian Women from 1988 to 2003, including annual reports, by-laws, membership directories, scholarship committee, budgets, scrapbook of clippings and photographs. Donated by Janet Bergman.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series contains scrapbooks prepared by Columbian Women historians from 1894 to 1985.

did.unittitle: History of Columbian Women, scholarships and applications, minutes, correspondence, and treasurer's reports

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series includes the history of Columbian Women, scholarships and applications, minutes, correspondence, and treasurer's reports. They date from 1947 to 1986.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series contains records of the Treasurer, the Scholarship Committee, and correspondence. They date from 1969 to 1997.

did.unittitle: National Bank of Washington Checking Account
National Bank of Washington Savings Account

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series contains directories, press releases, flyers, correspondence, invitations, programs, newspaper clippings, meeting minutes, reports, by-laws, memorandums, biographical information, and written histories. They range in date from 1897 to 2005. The materials concern membership directories, scholarships, events, "Security's Envoy", exhibits, history, and individual members.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series contains seven U-matic tapes from the Columbian Women. They range in date from 1977-1978.

did.unittitle: Columbian Women: U matic tape, "Bridging the Gap"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains correspondence, flyers, a directory, meeting minutes, financial records, and articles. The records date from 1966-2009. These records were compiled by Ramona Stoltz. Ms. Stolz graduated from GW with a B.A. in International Affairs. Ms. Stoltz has been a member of Columbian Women for more than ten years and has served in many leadership positions including president, first vice president, and as a member of the planning team for the 2003 Women's Leadership Conference.

did.unittitle: Directory of the Columbian Women of the George Washington University
